content:
Like our predecessors, we dare to dream big and connect people.

It all started with Leland Stanford, an industrial railroad tycoon who built the Central Pacific Railroad—a 19th century highway that catalyzed the exchange of new cultures and ideas. Stanford’s 1876 mansion became a relic of inspired luxury in the lush Nob Hill neighborhood until it was destroyed in a fire during the 1906 San Francisco earthquake. In 1912, investor Lucien H. Sly transformed the vacant lot into the posh Stanford Court Apartments. 60 years and a dramatic debut later, Stanford’s legacy stands today at the Stanford Court Hotel.

Now, we continue to champion San Francisco’s “boom town” spirit—the tenacity instilled by the risk takers and visionaries of the California Gold (and Silicon) Rush. We get it. You want a residential experience in Nob Hill. Well, we wanted to create a place that felt like the best version of home…a place we’d happily welcome our friends (with housekeeping!). Stanford Court offers the perfect mix of character, tech, and style, with all the comforts of a great boutique hotel in a “real” neighborhood. From the Gold Rush to the tech boom, a unique collection of risk takers, visionaries, and renegades have written the story of San Francisco. The walls of Stanford Court honor this ongoing legacy.
